items.title: They couldn’t locate 3 guns for 7 months. Now Halifax RCMP have made changes
items.summary_auto: RCMP in Halifax have changed how they keep track of guns after they were unable to account for three carbines for seven months.

items.title: Stepfather of missing N.S. children facing charges involving adult
items.summary_auto: Daniel Martell, the stepfather of two children who disappeared from their Pictou County home nearly nine months ago, is facing three charges.

items.title: Israel releases bodies of 15 Palestinians in final exchange of truce deal's 1st phase
items.summary_auto: The bodies of 15 more unidentified Palestinians were handed over by Israel Thursday, in the final exchange of prisoners and detainees between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: Post-Davos, Carney’s speech in Quebec is causing an uproar
items.summary_auto: Two days after receiving a standing ovation at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Prime Minister Mark Carney made an address in Quebec City that caused an uproar among Quebec's political class.

items.title: Cryptosporidium confirmed in water treatment plant in Kashechewan First Nation
items.summary_auto: An official with Kashechewan First Nation in northern Ontario says 63 community members have now tested positive for cryptosporidium, with test results showing water from the treatment plant has also tested positive for the parasite.

items.title: Cryptosporidium confirmed in Kashechewan First Nation water treatment plant, 63 test positive for parasite
items.summary_auto: An official with Kashechewan First Nation in northern Ontario says 63 community members have now tested positive for cryptosporidium, with test results showing water from the treatment plant has also tested positive for the parasite.

items.title: India reports 2 Nipah virus cases. What the infection is and how it spreads
items.summary_auto: India has confirmed two cases of the deadly Nipah virus. Here are answers on what the infection is and what happened in previous outbreaks in Asian countries.

items.title: What to know about the Nipah virus after cases emerge in India
items.summary_auto: India has confirmed two cases of the deadly Nipah virus. Here are answers on what the infection is and what happened in previous outbreaks in Asian countries.

items.title: No sea ice, no problem for these Barents Sea bears — for now
items.summary_auto: Studying close to 800 bears over nearly 25 years shows that polar bear populations in the rapidly warming Barents Sea, off the northern coasts of Norway and Russia, are doing better than polar bears in other parts of the Arctic.

items.title: B.C. premier says Alberta separatists seeking assistance from U.S. is 'treason'
items.summary_auto: British Columbia Premier David Eby says Alberta separatists meeting with the U.S. administration and seeking financial backing is an act of "treason," as the issue of national sovereignty loomed over a meeting between the premiers and Prime Minister Mark Carney Thursday.

items.title: U.S. government shutdown imminent unless Trump agrees to rein in ICE
items.summary_auto: Democrats have blocked budget legislation in the U.S. Senate, a move that will trigger a federal government shutdown on Friday unless the Trump administration agrees to change how its Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers conduct their controversial crackdown.

items.title: Canadian mining firm says 10 employees abducted in Sinaloa, Mexico
items.summary_auto: A Vancouver-based mining company says 10 of its employees were abducted from one of its project sites in the city of Concordia in the western Mexican state of Sinaloa, which has been gripped by a cartel civil war since 2024.

items.title: Trump border czar Tom Homan promises more targeted immigration enforcement in Minnesota
items.summary_auto: U.S. border czar Tom Homan, newly installed as commander of President Donald Trump's immigration enforcement surge in Minneapolis, promised targeted and strategic enforcements focusing on unauthorized residents with a criminal history.

items.title: Tariff war cost Canadian Pacific $200M over past year, CEO says
items.summary_auto: Canadian Pacific Kansas City Ltd. has suffered a $200-million blow from the ongoing tariff war set off by the United States, said CEO Keith Creel.

items.title: Home to the world’s largest lamp, this small Alberta village is deciding its next chapter
items.summary_auto: A central Alberta community is divided on a crucial vote to determine its future — whether it should continue existing as a village or be dissolved into the neighbouring county.

items.title: FBI carries out search warrant for 2020 election ballots at Atlanta-area site
items.summary_auto: The FBI on Wednesday searched the election office of a Georgia county that has been central to right-wing conspiracy theories over U.S. President Donald Trump's 2020 election loss, acting just one week after the Republican leader predicted prosecutions over a contest he has baselessly insisted was tainted by widespread fraud.

items.title: Lockdown lifted in Cree Nation of Mistissini in Quebec after 2 men fatally shot
items.summary_auto: The Cree Nation of Mistissini has lifted a lockdown put in place early Thursday after two men in their 30s were killed in a shooting.

items.title: Canada's Dabrowski, new partner eliminated in Australian Open women's doubles semifinal
items.summary_auto: Canada's Gabriela Dabrowski and Brazil's Luisa Stefani fell 7-6 (2), 3-6, 6-4 to Kazakhstan's Anna Danilina and Serbia's Aleksandra Krunic in the women's doubles semifinals at the Australian Open on Thursday in Melbourne.

items.title: B.C. woman urges dog owners to watch their pets on walks after husky overdoses on cocaine
items.summary_auto: A British Columbia woman is warning dog owners to watch what their pets touch on walks, after her two-year-old husky overdosed on cocaine. The Canadian Veterinary Medical Association says this is a problem across Canada. While it doesn't collect data on dog overdoses, it says, anecdotally, vets are seeing more of them.

items.title: Faced with surging demand, Alberta broke housing construction records. Is there a lesson there?
items.summary_auto: Alberta broke housing construction records in 2025 and led the country in housing starts per capita. The massive upswing in homebuilding comes after a period of similarly massive population growth, and some experts say there are lessons other cities in Canada could learn about how to ramp up housing supply to meet demand.

items.title: General Motors to lay off up to 1,200 workers in Oshawa, Ont., on Friday
Optimism is 'kind of a lie,' says Natalie Portman. And that's what makes Arco hopeful
items.summary_auto: Star and co-producer Natalie Portman and writer-director Ugo Bienvenu speak to CBC News about their Oscar-nominated film Arco and how it rejects fatalistic ideas of optimism or pessimism.

items.title: 9 years after mosque attack, paralyzed survivor says Quebec secularism laws hinder progress
items.summary_auto: Nine years after a deadly mosque attack in Quebec City claimed the lives of six men, survivors and advocates say they’re focused on promoting understanding — particularly in the wake of several pieces of legislation reinforcing secularism in Quebec.

items.title: Advocates criticize decision to keep aging Thunder Bay, Ont., correctional facilities open
items.summary_auto: When Sol Mamakwa visited the Thunder Bay District Jail last month, he said he witnessed beds pressed up against toilets in overcrowded cells. After learning that the facility, which turns 100 this year, is being kept open, Kiiwetinoong's MPP said “I was appalled.” Here are some reactions to the news that the Thunder Bay Correctional Complex under construction will not replace the city's existing correctional facilities.

items.title: Should the Canadian Coast Guard be armed? The jury is still out, but the navy says no
items.summary_auto: Canada is the only Arctic nation that doesn't arm its coast guard fleet. The United States, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Denmark, Iceland and Russia all operate coast guard fleets that have the capability to defend themselves. The commander of Canada's navy says arming the civilian fleet isn't necessary unless there's a war.

items.title: Poilievre courts delegates as he faces a must-win leadership review vote
items.summary_auto: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre's fate will be put to delegates at the party's convention in Calgary on Friday. While those around him are confident he can avoid being turfed, the leader's loyalists are doing all they can to ensure he easily clears this must-win vote.

items.title: Misleading videos on social media are targeting travellers to Canada for FIFA World Cup
items.summary_auto: Videos making false claims about Canada's immigration policies are popping up on TikTok and Instagram in an attempt to scam travellers coming to FIFA World Cup matches this summer, according to immigration and anti-fraud experts.

items.title: Alleged drug lord Ryan Wedding sought injunction to prevent arrest a year ago, legal documents show
items.summary_auto: Longtime fugitive Ryan Wedding sought a court order to prevent his arrest in Mexico’s Sinaloa state nearly a year before he was finally taken into U.S. custody last week, according to Mexican legal records obtained by CBC News. The documents suggest the Canadian, who is accused of leading a cocaine-smuggling network linked to the Sinaloa cartel, believed Mexican authorities were closing in on him in early 2025.

items.title: GM Canada layoffs hit Oshawa plant, putting up to 1,200 autoworkers out of work Friday
items.summary_auto: The day Oshawa, Ont., autoworkers have dreaded for months has arrived, as GM Canada is poised to cut a shift at the city’s plant, costing over a thousand workers their jobs.

items.title: Advocates fear Marineland whales, dolphins may be in shows or bred if export to U.S. approved
items.summary_auto: Canada’s minister of fisheries says Marineland’s plan to ship 34 marine mammals to aquariums in the U.S. is "solid." Animal advocates, meanwhile, worry the beluga whales and dolphins at the shuttered Niagara Falls, Ont., park may end up being used for breeding and performances if Ottawa approves the park's relocation request.

items.title: Nearly $7M of taxpayer funds spent on ostrich cull in Edgewood, B.C., data reveals
items.summary_auto: Federal officials have revealed that the total expenditures incurred during a controversial cull at a B.C. ostrich farm last year amounted to nearly $7 million.

items.title: County in Virginia opposes sale, conversion of Pattison-owned warehouse to ICE facility
items.summary_auto: A gigantic warehouse across the street from an outdoor equipment store has become a flashpoint in Virginia as the U.S. grapples with the Trump administration's immigration crackdown — and a British Columbia company has been pulled into the fray.

items.title: 5-year-old detained in Minneapolis last week still in Texas detention facility with his father
items.summary_auto: Two U.S. Democratic Representatives visited a five-year-old Ecuadorian boy and his father at a Texas federal detention centre Wednesday, in a case that has stirred anger over the Trump administration's immigration crackdown and given fuel to Democrats and others pushing back against the actions of ICE.

items.title: Vancouver tech company Hootsuite facing backlash for contract with U.S. Homeland Security, which oversees ICE
items.summary_auto: CEO Irina Novoselsky said Hootsuite has worked with government organizations across countries and administrations for more than 15 years, including the U.S. government.
